structure.hours: 12 hours of night, each with challenges

realmDetails.description: The Egyptian underworld through which the sun god Ra travels nightly and souls of the dead must navigate

name: Egyptian Underworld Journey
connections: Nile River - above-world counterpart (mirrors Duat structure)
Nun - primordial waters surrounding the journey
Fields of Aaru - final destination for blessed
Lake of Fire - place of judgment and purification
description:
The Duat is the Egyptian underworld, a realm of darkness, danger, and transformation that must be traversed
                each night by Ra in his solar barque and by the souls of the deceased seeking eternal life. The journey through
                the Duat's twelve hours represents the sun's passage from west (death/sunset) to east (rebirth/dawn), mirroring
                the soul's journey from death to resurrection.
displayName: ðŸŒ™ The Duat - Journey Through Night

richMetadata.structure: The Duat is organized as a vertical journey through 12 hours of night, each hour presenting distinct challenges, gates, and landscapes. Ra's solar barque travels eastward through four main divisions: entry halls, water realms, dangerous passages, and transformation chambers.
connections: Nile River - above-world counterpart (mirrors Duat structure)
Nun - primordial waters surrounding the journey
Fields of Aaru - final destination for blessed
Lake of Fire - place of judgment and purification
richMetadata.significance: The Duat represents the cyclical regeneration of life through death. It embodies the principle of transformation and daily resurrection, essential to Egyptian beliefs about immortality and the eternal return. The journey ensures cosmic order (Ma'at) is maintained.
parallels: Sumerian descent of Inanna - underworld journey
Greek Underworld - realm of the dead
Mesopotamian Irkalla - land of no return
sources: Book of the Dead (Pert em Hru)
